newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: OLYMPICS-ARGENTINA UPBEAT AFTER IOC EVALUATION.
newsitem.headline: OLYMPICS-ARGENTINA UPBEAT AFTER IOC EVALUATION.

text.p: Argentina was upbeat on Friday after the IOC's evaluation of Buenos Aires' bid to host the 2004 Olympics.
"We are very satisfied and optimistic about the evaluation," Francisco Mayorga, the Argentine tourism secretary and former racing driver heading the city's Olympic bid, told a news conference.
Buenos Aires' bid to become the first South American city to host the Games is based on promoting itself as the "safe" option for the event.
The bid committee argued that Buenos Aires had a low level of street crime for a city of its size.
The evaluation gave Buenos Aires, bidding for the fifth time, high marks for its local awareness and support as well as for the existing standard of certain venues and facilities.
However, it drew attention to a number of weaknesses, including a lack of accomodation and the need for a new international airport.
A short-list of five of the 11 cities competing to host the Games will be announced on March 7 with the winner named on September 5.
Mayorga was optimistic that Buenos Aires would reach the short-list.
"Abroad, they are falling in love more and more with our city...the remodelling going on day by day contributes a lot to their fascination," he said.
Mayorga played down the fact that Rome and Athens had emerged from the evaluation as front-runners.
"I will limit myself to the experience I have gained after 30 years in car racing -- until one sees the flag it's not possible to say who will win."
However, he promised that if Latin American rival Rio de Janeiro was short-listed ahead of Buenos Aires he would support its bid.
